poem:
Seascraper

Briny path,  
shrimp fisher's song,  
stifled in nets,  
a mother's lull.  
Fog hugs  
the coast's sharp edge—  
whispers of a story,  
sea-dampened,  
breath of salt  
in an unseen tide,  
lapping soft  
in pages turned—  
a seagull's call  
above the crests.  
What dreams  
linger here,  
unwritten, unsung?
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Seascraper by Benjamin Wood review – a story that sings on the page You don’t think you need a novella about a folk-singing shrimp fisher living with his mother on a fictional stretch of isolated coast until you read Benjamin Wood’s Booker-longlisted fifth novel, Seascraper. Wood conjures wonders from this unlikely material in a tale so richly atmospheric you can almost taste the tang of brine and inhale the sea fog. As unexpected as his". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
